awd_titl_txt: Theoretical Spectroscopy and Thermodynamics of Correlated Electron Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

Discoveries of new functional materials are crucial for technology advancement as well as for economic development, and advanced computational methods are accelerating progress in this area. This award supports research and education towards the acceleration of progress in our understanding of complex materials, which manifest prominent competition between quantum effects such as magnetism, superconductivity, and strongly correlated electron behavior.

In simpler materials, for which model representations in terms of a system of independent particles suffices, advanced methods have enabled large-scale simulations of the physical properties of realistic systems. For materials exhibiting correlated electron behavior, where the behavior of one electron is strongly dependent on that of other electrons in the material, the Dynamical Mean Field Theory method has enabled practical and accurate calculations of basic material properties. This project focuses on the development of software that simulates such complex materials with a computer, and which can predict material properties. The focus is in improving the precision of the theory, and in developing new theoretical spectroscopy tools, which will enable the prediction of the precise crystal structures of correlated solids, and the prediction of actual spectroscopic measurements made using neutron and x-ray scattering experimental techniques.

The project will lead to the development of algorithms and software that will be incorporated in open-source code packages, which subsequently will be made available to the wider research community. These tools will help the materials science community to find promising material candidates for synthesis, which should further enable theory-assisted material discovery and design. Training and mentorship of junior researchers will also take place as part of the project, contributing to the development of scientific workforce.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY: 

In the search for new materials with enhanced physical properties it is crucial to develop broad capabilities for computational characterization. This award supports research and education towards the development of a number of theoretical spectroscopic tools, which can be used in combination with electronic structure tools. The latter are based on Dynamical Mean Field Theory (developed under previous NSF support), and enable theoretical prediction of material properties using first-principles methods. The spectroscopic tools and methods that will be developed in this project include: i) relaxation of complex crystal structures using forces on all atoms in the unit cell, which will enable prediction of complex crystal structures; ii) extension of the calculation of forces to materials with large spin-orbit coupling; iii) developing a tool to predict phase transitions in systems with strongly coupled crystal- and electronic structure; iv) developing a tool to calculate phonons in correlated materials; v) developing x-ray scattering spectroscopy that properly takes into account the core-hole interaction.

These tools will be made available to the broader scientific community as they will be incorporated in the PI's electronic structure software package, which is widely used, and is distributed as open-source; see: http://hauleweb.rutgers.edu/tutorials/. The overall goal of the research is to build a predictive framework for describing the physical properties of correlated materials, to experimentally validate it, by close collaboration with material scientists to test the predictions of the computational theory, and to improve it in the areas of disagreement. Training and mentorship of junior researchers will also take place as part of the project, contributing to the development of scientific workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In a world driven by technological advancements, our understanding of materials plays a crucial role in the development of innovative technologies. This project has delved into the intriguing realm of complex materials, seeking solutions to the enigmas posed by correlated materials?materials characterized by the interplay of quantum effects, such as electron correlation, magnetism, and superconductivity, and their connection to the lattice structure.
The scope of this work goes beyond theoretical exploration, extending to the education and training of young scientists, thereby nurturing the next generation of researchers.
The team has developed state-of-the-art algorithms and theoretical methods for predicting properties correlated materials, specifically the Embedded Dynamical Mean Field Theory (eDMFT), which is combined with the standard Density Functional Theory (DFT). For simpler materials, where physical properties can be accurately represented in terms of a system of independent particles in the presence of an average potential, DFT methods have enabled large-scale simulations of realistic systems. However, for correlated materials, which cannot be treated in this averaged manner, the Dynamical Mean Field Theory (DMFT) method has enabled practical, precise calculations of the fundamental properties of correlated solids. This proposal focuses on developing the synergy between these two methods, allowing the team to deepen their understanding of the physical properties in promising correlated materials. To achieve this, the team has developed theoretical spectroscopy tools to predict various physical properties of complex correlated matter.
Furthermore, the team has devised a numerically exact method based on diagrammatic Monte Carlo techniques, known as the Variational Diagrammatic Monte Carlo method. This method was applied to address a pivotal challenge in the field, which lies at the core of Density Functional Theory?the uniform electron gas problem. The innovative method successfully converged in the metallic range of densities, offering a numerically exact solution to this problem within this regime.
Identifying materials with enhanced properties requires computational characterization. The team has developed a suite of theoretical spectroscopic tools that, when combined with electronic structure methods, can predict material properties from first principles?eliminating the reliance on experimental data. Throughout this project, the team employed these theoretical methods to gain novel insights into a diverse range of correlated materials, spanning from elemental iron, iron superconductors, manganites with giant magnetoresistance, iron-molybdenum systems with a giant magneto-electric effect, to double bilayer graphene at a magic angle, exhibiting superconductivity near a Mott insulating state.
The project has encompassed a wide range of major activities, including the development of the exact many-body method, Variational Diagrammatic Monte Carlo, the creation of a novel impurity solver, and the further refinement of eDMFT to gain insights into real-world materials. These activities have significantly advanced the field of materials science.
The impact of this research extends well beyond theoretical physics. The algorithms and methodologies developed here have found applications in various disciplines, including experimental physics, material science, chemistry, nanoscience, and device engineering. For instance, these tools are now being adopted in quantum chemistry.
Teaching remains a cornerstone of this endeavor, and the PI has made educational resources readily available on YouTube, particularly through his course on computational physics. The team has also developed online tutorials for the eDMFT software package and expanded the materials database, enhancing accessibility and usability for students and researchers alike. To facilitate the sharing of knowledge and code, the researchers have made their software available on platforms like GitHub, enabling a global community to benefit from their work.
